Definition: In this task, you're given four sentences of a story written in natural language, and one last sentence (Sentence5). Your job is to determine whether the last sentence completes the story coherently or not, by outputting 'Yes' or 'No'.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 Sentence5: He is happy now.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 Sentence5: Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious and she should not cancel going to her friend's party.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 Sentence5 Sarah then decided to move to Europe.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different; Sarah cannot decide to move to Europe.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 Sentence5: He is happy now.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. So, output should be Yes because Sentencce5 properly ends the story

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 Sentence5: Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Negative Examples.explanation: The answer can only be Yes or No.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 Sentence5 Sarah then decided to move to Europe.
Negative Examples.output: Answer can be Sarah returned to the home.
Negative Examples.explanation: The answer can only be Yes or No.

Instances.input:
Sentence1: Carl looked into a telescope for the first time at 9-Year's-old. Sentence2: He was immediately breath-taken and full of wonder. Sentence3: He decided he had to learn more about the cosmos. Sentence4: He studied science and astronomy through high school and college. 
 Sentence5: He ended up becoming a scientist.

Sentence1: Alice was getting married in a few weeks. Sentence2: One night, her mother called and she forgot to call her back. Sentence3: Her mother left an angry message on her phone. Sentence4: She threatened not to come to the wedding. 
 Sentence5: Alice called her mother and apologized profusely.

Sentence1: Larry was playing golf with his father. Sentence2: Larry was feeling really energetic from his coffee earlier. Sentence3: He hit the ball as hard as he could on his first swing. Sentence4: Larry got a hole in one! 
 Sentence5: Larry was mad about his score.

Sentence1: Francis has always looked forward to learning how to drive. Sentence2: Finally he is old enough for a driver's license. Sentence3: Francis studies very hard to get a license. Sentence4: He passes his driver's test easily. 
 Sentence5: Francis decides he would rather take public transportation.

Sentence1: I was walking to the mall. Sentence2: Someone was calling me and I decided to pull out my phone. Sentence3: I had a hard time getting it out since my pockets were tight. Sentence4: The phone ended up jumping out of my pocket. 
 Sentence5: I decided tight jeans were a good idea always.

Sentence1: Fred went to the beach with his friends. Sentence2: He loved the water and the sunshine. Sentence3: His friends threw a party on the beach after the sun went down. Sentence4: Fred got drunk and passed out on the sand. 
 Sentence5: Fred woke up with a hangover.

Sentence1: Fred always stopped at the same coffee shop before work. Sentence2: He got to know the attractive barista. Sentence3: He developed a crush on her. Sentence4: Finally Fred worked up the courage to ask her on a date. 
 Sentence5: Fred told the barista to leave him alone.

Sentence1: Jill went to college. Sentence2: Jill studied really hard. Sentence3: Jill passed all her tests. Sentence4: Jill got her diploma. 
 Sentence5: Jill frequently ate lima beans.
